intro: Drymosiphon piperelloides, commonly known as the pipe-like liverwort, is a non-vascular plant belonging to the family Porellaceae. It is characterized by its elongated, tubular thallus that resembles a pipe, hence its common name. This species typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as on rocks or tree trunks in tropical and subtropical regions. The plant lacks true roots, stems, and leaves, instead having a structure composed of a central axis covered in small, leaf-like structures called phyllidia. Its reproductive structures, known as gametangia, are located at the tips of the thallus, facilitating sexual reproduction through spore dispersal.
